audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker addressing the subject of celebrities and veganism. He speaks in a conversational tone, suggesting that some celebrities are being paid to be plant-based while others couldn't maintain the diet. He cites Angelina Jolie as an example, saying that she claimed the diet nearly ended her life because she wasn't getting enough nutrition.

The clip starts with a male speaker stating that the beauty secret is "big, juicy steaks." He follows this up with how women would be choking down sticks of butter every single supermarket and how the media has women under the belief that eating meat is not conducive to beauty. He then mentions Dax Shepard and Kristen Bell deciding to go vegan in 2012 after watching Forks Over Knives, with both struggling with the switch and Kristen being a vegetarian who enjoys the occasional dairy product. The speech has an informative and somewhat sarcastic tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, sounding judgmental, who mentions a couple that supports a plant-based lifestyle and launched a vegan baby line, “Hello Bello,” and questions if this makes them evil, implying they are “demons disguised as humans.” The speaker references Jared Leto, who credits his youth to sleep and a vegan diet, calling him a “cheating vegan,” and expresses his frustration with the glamorization of vegan diets. The clip ends abruptly with the last word.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing skepticism about vegans, claiming they "continuously lie" about who is vegan. He cites examples like Channing Tatum, who only practiced veganism for a short time, and Meghan Markle, who ate vegan during the week. The speaker's tone is critical, bordering on mocking, as he questions the glamorization of a vegan diet. His delivery is consistent throughout the clip. There are no other sounds present.

The audio clip features one male speaker, who initially uses a sarcastic tone to describe someone getting mugged repeatedly, followed by an example of a celebrity personal trainer being criticized by vegans. The speaker then transitions to a mocking tone, questioning the nature of vegans. There is no music or ambient sounds present.

The clip opens with one male speaker in a critical tone, warning against eating tofu. He then mentions a person named Stevo who was vegan for a decade but started eating fish in 2019, and points out the vegan community dislikes this. He quotes Stevo as saying "vegans can be annoying" and their views can pit people against you, before posing the question of whether anyone is truly vegan. The speaker recalls a previous video about bug butter and mentions the amount of insect parts in plant-based food, concluding by asking if consuming insects means you are not vegan.

The clip begins with a male speaker mentioning "vegan", followed by details about Waka Flocka Flame expressing frustration with vegans. The speaker mentions Waka Flocka Flame giving up a plant-based lifestyle and his perception that other vegans acted like "the cops". Waka Flocka Flame also disliked how "vegan" made him "sound like he felt superior to others".

The clip starts with a male speaker describing how Beyonce and Jay-Z explored veganism, "issued a 22-day vegan challenge" and encouraged people to buy their cookbook, but that they are "not vegan," and still eat meat. He then says Chris Hemsworth "wore the vegan title" without being vegan. In a more sarcastic and dramatic tone, the same male speaker imagines himself pretending to be vegan and then seen "eating a fat juicy steak," and then saying "oh well" to his audience, adding that "vegan diet is still great." A short, high-pitched squealing sound effect then plays abruptly.

The audio clip features a single male speaker expressing skepticism, stating that "Ellen DeGeneres was allegedly on a strict plant-based diet for eight years, yeah, who believes that." He further mentions she now eats "fish and eggs" but "still promotes veganism." His tone is doubtful and somewhat critical. There are no identified music or background sounds present in the clip.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, sharing how Jennifer Lopez turned to veganism after giving birth to her twins. He mentions how it supposedly helped her energy levels soar and after her 22 day vegan challenge, she reintroduced lean meats and fish. The speaker then states this as a practical application of what a vegan diet should be, as a fast for your body. He then adds if you don't want to water fast or just starve yourself, consuming vegetables and fruits is a way of starving yourself.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing how "Samuel L. Jackson went vegan for seven months" after a health scare, resulting in so much weight loss he almost lost a film role. He states that Samuel L. Jackson ended his veganism "after going to a Shake Shack, not looking back since". The male speaker's tone is informative and slightly humorous.

The clip starts with a female speaker discussing that actress Lea Michele "keeps a vegan home". She goes on to say the actress stocks the home with fruits and vegetables. The female speaker quotes that Lea explains she was vegan for a while but has since incorporated meat and other animal products back into her life. A different speaker, a male, discusses why people reach for snacks and eat all day. He attributes it to starving for micronutrient nutrition, predominantly due to a lack of bioavailable fat-soluble vitamins from animal foods in the diet.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing professional dancer Derek Hough and his short-lived vegan diet, noting he only lasted about six weeks before succumbing to meat cravings, emphasizing that tolerance for vegan diets varies, some needing "to choke down some steak in two months," while others last longer. The speaker maintains a conversational tone throughout the discussion.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing Zoey Deschanel's dietary choices, noting her challenges with veganism and food sensitivities, and then shifts into a broader point about how media shapes public opinion. The speaker's tone is conversational and reflective. There's no noticeable background music or ambient sounds.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing veganism, referencing celebrities like Laverne Cox who found it difficult to maintain a vegan diet, and others like Carrie Underwood who are more "practical" in their approach, as well as others who ended up eating meat or fish again. The speaker adopts a slightly critical tone, questioning the consistency of some celebrities' vegan claims. This is briefly followed by an audio stinger.

The clip starts with a male speaker thanking listeners for joining, requesting that they "share the video", like and subscribe if they enjoyed it. He promotes Frankie's Free Range Meat, mentioning "a sale on brains for all of you zombies". He then advertises Frankie's Naturals for hygiene and cosmetic products and invites listeners to contact him for health consultations, remarking on the "overwhelming amount of former vegans reaching out". He ends by thanking the audience again and wishing them a good day. This is followed by slow, melancholic organ music.
